_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Training procedures have been updated and training on the new procedures will take place in early 2015
_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: A group quiz was given during each training session

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Precise Packaging facility, located in Fall River, Massachusetts provides contract filling, compounding and package development services for home fragrance, personal care, and pharmaceutical industries.  Aerosol container filling services at the facility utilize a series of eight  Liquefied Petroleum (LP) Gas tanks ( seven 3,500-gallon tanks, and two 1,500-gallon tanks) that house a combination of 1,1 Diflouroethane (DFE), Propane and Isobutane (Aerosols).  These exterior tanks serve a series of four exterior gas houses.  The aerosols are circulated through the gas house(s) in liquid form and injected into partially-filled and sealed aerosol containers. Pressurized containers return to the facility, via conveyor systems, for inspection and packaging. At maximum, the facility may store (for brief time periods) approximately 185,000 small (1 to 5 ounce) bottles of finished product awaiting shipment to customers.  Finished product bottles contain varying amounts of aerosol.  

At any given time, the assumed combined maximum inventory of 1,1 DFE, Propane and Isobutane is approximately 130,000 pounds (present in tanks and finished product). 1,1 DFE, Propane and Isobutane are covered substances under the Risk Management Program, each with an applicability threshold of 10,000 pounds.  As such, the Precise Packaging facility is subject to the RMP requirements.  

Based on the evaluation performed by ERM in conjunction with Precise Packaging personnel, it was determined that the facility is eligible for classification under the Program level 3 requirements.   A covered process is subject to Program 3 if the process is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard, 29 CFR 1910.119, and does not meet the Program Level 1 eligibility conditions which, among other things, require that the facility must analyze the worst-case release scenario for the covered process(es) and document that the nearest public receptor is beyond the distance to a toxic or flammable en
llant and flammable liquids.  An experienced work force, supported by a dedicated Senior Management team, has combined to maintain an environment where safety is of the highest priority.

dpoint, as defined in 40 CFR 68.22(a).

Based on a series of offsite consequence analyses (OCAs) performed using the EPA's RMP *Comp Modeling tool, the worst case consequence scenario resulting from a catastrophic release of each of the three propellants present on site are as follows:
¿	Release of 26,565 pounds of 1,1 DFE from a 3,500 gallon tank would result in a flammable (overpressure) endpoint of 1,056-feet (0.2 miles).  At this distance, no residential or environmental receptors located beyond the property boundaries surrounding the facility would be impacted by such a release.  It should be noted, however, that several industrial facilities and a recreational use area (Watuppa Reservation) would fall within the flammable endpoint.  
¿	Release of 14,770 pounds of Propane from a 3,500-gallon tank would result in a flammable (overpressure) endpoint of 1,056-feet (0.2 miles).  At this distance, no residential or environmental receptors located beyond the property boundaries surrounding the facility would be impacted by such a release.  It should be noted, however, that several industrial facilities and a recreational use area (Watuppa Reservation) would fall within the flammable endpoint.  
¿	Release of 16,450 pounds of Isobutane from a 3,500-gallon tank would result in a flammable (overpressure) endpoint of 1,056-feet (0.2 miles).  At this distance, no residential or environmental receptors located beyond the property boundaries surrounding the facility would be impacted by such a release.  It should be noted, however, that several industrial facilities and a recreational use area (Watuppa Reservation) would fall within the flammable endpoint.  

As part of the OCA process, a review of typical by-products and/or decomposition products of DFE when released into the atmosphere was performed.  Based on the data included in the MSDS DFE is a stable compound and does not readily react with water in the environment.  However, DFE is flammable and under a combus

tion scenario (i.e., explosion) DFE will decompose to carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, halogenated compounds, and/or carbonyl halides.  Among these halogenated compounds, hydrogen fluoride (HF) could be created.

ERM performed a review of typical by-products and/or decomposition products of DFE when released into the atmosphere.  Based on the data included in the Safety Data Sheet, DFE is a stable compound and does not readily react with water in the environment.  However, DFE is flammable and under a combustion scenario (i.e., explosion) DFE will decompose to carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, halogenated compounds, and/or carbonyl halides.  Among these halogenated compounds, hydrogen fluoride (HF) could be created.

For RMP purposes, a worst case theoretical scenario regarding HF formation assumes that during an explosion the maximum DFE stored at the facility (62,500 pounds) is completely consumed and all halogenated compounds produced are HF.  Based on the molecular structure of DFE, C2H4F2, there are two fluorine atoms available for HF formation for every molecule of DFE.  Using the molecular weight of DFE (66.05 lb/lbmole), approximately 946.25 lbmoles of DFE is the maximum storage quantity on site.  If every fluorine atom were to convert to HF during an explosion (a 2:1 ratio), 18,925 lbmoles of HF would be produced.  Using the molecular weight of HF (20.01 lb/lbmole), this would equate to a maximum theoretical release of approximately 37,868.25 lbs HF.  This level would be above the identified action level thresholds with respect to HF exposure. 

There have been no accidental releases of propellant from the facility in the past five years.  There have been no accidental releases of alcohol from the facility in the past five years.  There have been no accidental releases of any hazardous chemicals from the facility in the past fifteen years.

Through this long-term record of zero releases, PRECISE has demonstrated a commitment to safe handling of prope
